Who am I?

I am an astrophysicist with a passion for data visualization and problem solving. Through big data processing, I am interested in understanding, extracting, and presenting the meaningful value hidden in data.

Born and raised in Italy, I completed my undergraduate studies in Astrophysics and Cosmology at the Alma mater studiorum - University of Bologna. I then moved to Munich, Germany, where I obtained my PhD degree at the Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität.

After a postdoc at Stockholm University, I am currently employed as a researcher at Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, in the astrophysics, cosmology, and artificial intelligence group of Prof. Daniel Gruen. My work focuses on observational and computational cosmology. I am interested in the study of cosmic large-scale structures, dynamics and formation of galaxies, and determination of the nature of dark matter and dark energy.

My Work

Galaxy Clusters

Galaxy clusters are the result of the gravitational collapse of overdense regions that are seeded by processes in the early universe, followed by a sequence of mergers and accretion of surrounding material. These structures are important laboratories for investigations of structure formation and galaxy evolution, as well as useful cosmological probes. Through my work, I try to shed light on their history, their formation and how they fit within the larger cosmological framework. To understand the physics of these objects, I perform dynamical analyses using member galaxies as tracers of the clusters' gravitational potential.

Find out more

Cosmology & Large-Scale Structure

I apply advanced statistical methods, such as machine learning, to big astrophysical datasets to compare models with the observed Universe.
